page.title: 04NORTHUMBRIAN DIALECT
page.content: The Northumbrian dialect as spoken in Whalton and the immediate area varies little from that of a century ago. However, with the demise of many of the old village families and the influx of more business and professional people together with the modern education system, the broad accent is heard less nowadays. In fact a true Northumbrian dialect speaker is almost regarded as a 'turn' at a local concert. The dialect is produced by a flattening or broadening of the vowels. Real Whaltonians invariably leave off the 'g' in such words as goin', hangin' etc, and use 'aa' instead of I. They are also prone to use 'a', as in canna, when meaning cannot. Whalton becomes Whaaltun as opposed to Whaatun which was used in the last century.
